Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Evacuate or Not? Modeling the Decision Making of Individuals in Impending Disaster Areas

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
A category 4 hurricane is approaching. Should a potentially affected individual follow the official orders and evacuate, or stay in place? Millions of individuals situated in vulnerable areas face this grave question as imminent disaster threatens. Many choose to leave, whereas some do not. Numerous interviews with such persons clearly convey their conviction in having made the right choice. This RAPID project will identify the variables that significantly influence the decision making of individuals in impending disaster areas, and it will contribute to the understanding of how the variables are utilized differently by different individuals. These insights will help to build new computational models of the individual's decision making under uncertainty, in extreme situations such as hurricanes and other natural disasters. The focus disasters will be the impacts of Hurricane Harvey on the Texas coast and Hurricane Irma on Florida and Georgia. Outcomes could augment evacuation efforts with actions on the ground that target those most likely to ignore official recommendations. Furthermore, such modeling will likely help relief-and-rescue efforts to better coordinate and provide faster relief with increased precision. Outcomes from this research will be integrated into the classroom instruction of courses taught by the PIs, which will provide students with exposure to how decision-making science can have real-world impact even under the most extreme circumstances.

The technical approach begins with characterizing the affected classes of individuals of interest. Next, various types of data about them will be gathered. In particular, interviews of affected individuals before the impending disaster and after, as reported by various news agencies, relevant social media messages originating from disaster areas, government data on evacuees and their demographics, and other survey instruments will be used to build a comprehensive data set for analysis. These data will be sifted to infer the significant variables and how they interact in individual decision making. The analysis and data will be used to build empirically-informed decision making models, which will combine principled agent-based modeling with parametric human judgment and choice models. The exploratory nature of this research makes model evaluation particularly important. Performance of the various models on the data will be compared based on their fits and qualitative assessments. This research plan is expected to yield validated models of the decision-making processes of several affected individuals for government use and further study.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Hurricanes Harvey and Irma in 2017 provided opportunities to study demographic and experiential predictors of evacuation behavior, including factors that differ between hurricanes. A Qualtrics panel targeted the 12 Texas counties evacuated during Hurricane Harvey, and the 23 Florida counties and 27 Georgia ZIP codes evacuated during Hurricane Irma. 822 respondents completed the survey 14-21 December 2017, including demographic and experiential variables related to evacuation. Younger adults and those who lived with children were more likely to evacuate. Perceived risk and previous trauma were associated with evacuation, but hurricane experience was not. In two logistic regressions, frequency of receiving evacuation orders and perceived risk remained as significant predictors, including subjective and objective measures of the degree to which others evacuate. Theoretical and policy implications are discussed.

We also examined the possible role of cognitive biases including gambler’s fallacy (GF) and illusion of control, excluding participants who gave contradictory responses about whether they were in an evacuation zone at the time of hurricane impact (N=785). When these participants were excluded, it improved the psychometric quality of the data, particularly between the two GF questions. However, this resulted in the key predictors of Evacuation (GF1 and IOC1) being nonsignificant. All cognitive predictor variables were dichotomous in nature, as was the target variable (evacuation). The appropriate correlation analysis revealed no significant correlation between evacuation choice and any of the cognitive bias variables.

The survey data and other known results from the hurricane modeling literature were then used to inform a new computational process model of the decision making of individuals in impending disaster areas. The previous statistical testing helped identify the variables that were used in the decision-making model. Our model is a factored partially observable Markov decision process, represented in the graphical language of dynamic influence diagrams, which is easy to comprehend and operate. Data from the survey responses were used to enter the evidence for the variables in the model and arrive at the decisions with a reasonably good mean accuracy of 71.77% with low variance. The descriptive process model aims to capture an individual’s actual decision making, and not normative recommendations (which was to evacuate for all surveyed individuals). Decision-making models that are reasonably accurate will have a significant positive impact on human lives saved and on planning for disaster aid.

Social media data pertaining to the behavior of individuals impacted by the two hurricanes was also collected to gain broader insights. About 700,000 tweets in English and Spanish were acquired from Twitter, Inc. that satisfied the criteria of being sent between August 16, 2017 and September 16, 2017 from a US location and  containing keywords related to the hurricanes. Retweets from specific accounts such as those of National Weather Service (NWS) Atlanta, NWS Corpus, NWS KeyWest, NWS Miami, NWS Tampa Bay; those of the police and fire rescue departments of the affected cities; those of FEMA, and several news agencies covering the two impending disasters were also obtained. Public Facebook pages of several local and national news agencies with content in the time period mentioned above were downloaded. Finally, several thousand online news articles containing keywords “hurricane”, “Harvey”, and “Irma”, and were written in the time period August 16, 2017 and September 16, 2017 were also scraped.

On this vast social media dataset, automated clustering was utilized to discover any frequent reasons for not evacuating (location, family, and pet were often mentioned); an accurate classifier was built to identify tweets that contained information about evacuation decision making, and these tweets were used to progrmamatically build individuals' timeline of evacuation behaviors.
